skills.name: Aleph-Bais 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Hello, and welcome to the Yiddish course!
------------------

**There are tips and notes for the majority of the skills, please take your time to read them. ** 

Whether you're learning Yiddish because your family used it as a secret language, or because you're curious about what the other language Middle High German split off into looks like, this course will help you get familiar with the Yiddish language. 

Because Yiddish uses the Hebrew alphabet, the writing system is written from ***right to left!***.

|English letters | Yiddish letters |
| -------- | --------- |
| m |  |
| a |  |
| n |  |
| man |  |

--------
The Yiddish Alphabet
--------

The Yiddish alphabet has no capitalization, instead, there are 5 letters that, when at the end of the word, change, just like the greek '/'. Those letters look different when written at the end of a word (their pronunciation **does not change**).

Each letter is given with the pronunciation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and a close-matching example in English:

**Please pay attention to the asterisks and !**

Name|Letter|Ending form|IPA|English example
---|---|---|---|---
Shtimer Alef|| |-| silent, used at the beginning of a word that starts with a vowel (except /ayin, /pasekh alef, and /kumits alef)
Kumits alef|| |/u~~/|**ooh/uh**/n**o**t (when said with a British accent) 
Pasekh alef|| |/~a/|h**o**p, st**o**p
Bays/Vays|| |/b/,/v/|**b**oy, **v**an
Vays** |**| |/v/**|**v**an
Gimel|| |/g/|**g**o
Daled|| |/d/|**d**og
Hay|| |/h/|**h**en
Vuv|| |/~i~i/ *, rarely/v*/*| b**oo**, **i**n, s**ee**, **v**an
Melipm vuv***|***| |/~i~i//*| b**oo**, **i**n, s**ee**
Zayin|| |/z/|**z**oo
Khes|| |//|lo**ch**
Tes|| |/t/| **t**en
Yeed|| |/j~i:~i/|**y**es, f**i**n, s**ee**
Khirik yeed***|***| |/i/|f**i**n
Kuf|| |/k/|**c**at
Khuf|||//|lo**ch**
Lamed|| |/l/|**l**og
Mem|||/m/|**m**an
Neein|||/n/|**n**o
Samekh|| |/s/|**s**ee
Ayin|| |//, /ej/|**eh**, h**ey** |
Pay|| |/p/|**p**an
Fay|||/f/|**f**our
Fay**|**||/f/|**f**our
Tsadik|||/ts/|ca**ts**
Keef|| |/k/|**c**at
Raysh|| |/r/|bo**tt**le (like the Spanish R/RR)
Sheein|| |//|**sh**e
Seein|| |/s/|**s**ea *notice the dot to the left*
Tuf|| |/t/|**t**ap
Suf|| |/s/|**s**o


*Very rarely used, in words of Semitic origin where the "v" sound is the first letter of the word, like , Vashti.

**Not used in this course; used in YIVO standard spelling.

***Only used to disambiguate when located adjacent to other letters with which it could theoretically combine (but doesn't).

 Only used in words of Semitic origin, like , dream.

- If there are any mistakes in the IPA, let us know. There is no official IPA for the Hungarian Yiddish dialect, which is the dialect used in this tree, so there might be some inaccurate IPAs.

skills.name: Hello!
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In English, for 'negative' sentences you can use (no/not a), but in Yiddish there exists only one option: .
"She is *not a* boy." = "She is *no* boy." 
For both of these you would simply say "" instead of "".
One important note for those of you who speak German:  (which is cognate with eine) does not mean "a" - it specifically means "one". So   is "one cat", not "a cat". The indefinite article is  or .

skills.name: Home
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Yiddish, like German, has three grammatical genders, meaning a word can be masculine, feminine, or neuter. Knowing the gender of the word is important, as it affects the words around it. It can seem overwhelming trying to remember the gender of each word, but don't worry! Here are a few tricks to help you out:
- If the word ends in a schwa sound, a vowel, or , then it is most likely feminine.
- If a word ends in , then it's most likely masculine.
- If the word is in the diminutive case, which indicates a smaller version of something, then it is always neuter.

Great! Now that you've got those useful tricks, here's one way you'll use them. The definite articles ("the") are dependent on the noun's gender. They are:
 for masculine ( , der kompyuter, the computer) 
 for feminine ( , di sofe, the sofa) 
 for neuter, ( , dus kind, the kid)

If there is a compound word, such as , which is +, it will almost always take the gender of the last word.

In Yiddish, when you say "not a..." the "a" becomes negative as well, and the negative 'a' in Yiddish is . 

    **** . The bed is not **a** house.


 = quite (**NOT** "very/so"),  = very (In Yiddish they are different!)

skills.name: Food 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In Yiddish, just like in English, there are only two indefinite articles, "a" and "an." They are used exactly like in English. Before a vowel sound,  / an is used. Before a consonant sound,  / a is used.

Examples:
  - an epl - an apple
  - a bar - a pear

skills.name: You
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Verb Conjugations**

In the skills You and Me, you will learn the first person present and the second person present conjugation. The first person present is just the base form of the verb (e.g.,  , I drink). The second person present conjugation is formed by adding  (e.g.,  ).

Here is a conjugation table of the verbs you'll learn in this skill:

|First Person|Second Person|
| -------- | --------- |
|   |   |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |

Note - the  and  drop away before the .*

* is an irregular verb

**Introducing Yourself**

In Yiddish, (like in French or Spanish), when you want to introduce yourself, you say "I am called..." The verb for this is , which means "to be called/named." So, if you want to tell someone your name, you can say "...  (Ikh hays..., I am called..., or My name is...)

skills.name: Me
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Verb Conjugations**

In the skills You and Me, you will learn the first person present and the second person present conjugation. The first person present is just the base form of the verb (e.g.,  , I drink). The second person present conjugation is formed by adding  (e.g.,  ).

|First Person|Second Person|
| -------- | --------- |
|   |   |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |

Note - the  and  drop away before the .*

* is an irregular verb

**The letter **

The letter  (kh) is only used in words of Semitic (e.g. Hebrew) origin.

**Important vocabulary**

: how much/many

 : also

  : a lot/many

  : no idea

 : not a lot/not many

skills.name: Questions
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Yiddish has two words for "how"!
1. When you're using "how" together with an adjective or an adverb - How old? How high? How quickly? - you would use " ("vi"). 
2. When you're using "how" together with a verb - How can I say this? How do you know him? How should we do this? - you would use "  ("vi azoy").

In questions, instead of saying   (you are), the words are inverted and the  drops off. 

  ->  (di bist -> bisti)

 ? Are you Sender?

 ->  (di hayst -> haysti)

 ? Are you Mirl?

skills.name: More
skills.tipsAndNotes:
A quick primer on possessives:
Singular -  means "my" and  means "your"
Plural - You add an  to the singular, so the plural possessive pronouns are , .

skills.name: Origin
skills.tipsAndNotes:
****

If youre asking where someone is from, instead of saying  , you say   or "  (both mean the same thing, it's just a dialectal difference).

**Living**

There are two ways to say "to live."  means to live, as in "to reside, while  means to live, as in to be alive.

**Coming from**

If youre saying youre from somewhere, you would use the verb ", meaning originate. Think of it as saying "stem" ("I stem from Poland"    .) So if youre asking someone where theyre from, youd say:  / ?

**Countrymen**

If you want to describe yourself as being from another country, you wouldn't use the adjective (e.g.,   ). You would say the equivalent of "I am a Frenchman" (i.e.,    ). In English, those constructions are generally archaic; the more natural translation is "I am French".

Yiddish actually has different words for "A Jew from xx" and "a person (usually implied non-Jew) from xx". A Jew from France would be called a ; someone who is not specifically Jewish would be called a . In this course, we teach the generic term.

**Standalone Possessive Pronouns**

Remember the genders we learned? Heres a situation where its important: If youre using a possessive pronoun on its own (e.g. That book is mine, vs. My book), the ending of the pronoun changes.
If the noun is masculine, you add  to the end -    , the computer is mine.
If the noun is feminine or plural, you add  to the end -    , the sofa is yours.
If the possessive pronoun is before the noun, it doesn't change.  ,  .

** and Yes/No Questions**

If you start a sentence with , it signals that youre asking a Yes/No question:

   ?

Do you have a cat? (Yes or no?)

If  is used in the middle of a sentence, it means either/or -      ? Do you have a computer *or* a bed? It must be *either* one of those, not neither.

skills.name: Need
skills.tipsAndNotes:
****

In English, you'd say you're "looking for" something. In Yiddish, this can be done in one word: . You don't say   because that is superfluous.

**/Nu**

 is a popular exclamation. It has many meanings, often depending on the tone of voice.
 
|Yiddish| English|
| -------- | --------- |
|  | agree |
|  | not so bad |
| ! | come on! |
|   | I've heard worse |
| ! | stop that right now! |
| ? | why are you telling me this? |
|   ... | don't you dare do that... |
| ... | go on... |
|  | get on with it |
| ? | well, spill the beans! |
|  | stop bothering me |
|  | that's all |

(taken from https://i.redd.it/9ci8z81ugab41.jpg)

**The Passive Voice**

In Yiddish, the passive voice is introduced using the pronoun //. Think of it as saying "one" in English.  In English, you might say "What is sold here/What does one sell here?" to ask about a shop, but in Yiddish, you would say    ? What does "one" sell here? In Yiddish, this pronoun is used VERY frequently, and sometimes it's used as the first person plural pronoun even, such as "We're working here!"   !

Whether you should use  or  or  depends on where it is in the sentence. If it is
before a verb starting with a vowel, you should use , such as 
before a verb starting with a consonant, you should use , such as  , one searches (we search)
After a verb, you should use . How does one eat this/How is this eaten becomes     ?

skills.name: Which
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The word 'which' in Yiddish has to match the gender of the noun that follows. If the accompanying noun is...
Masculine: Use . Which computer (m) is  .
Feminine:  Use . Which cat (f) is  .
Neuter:  Use . Which house (n) is  .

The word  gets conjugated like an adjective. You'll learn dative in a few lessons; it's only included here for completeness.

| | Nominative | Accusative | Dative |
| -------- | --------- | --------- | --------- |
| Masculine |  |  |  |
| Feminine |  |  |  |
| Neuter |  |  |  |

We learned , , , , and now we're teaching / for neuter.

skills.name: Time
skills.tipsAndNotes:
If you want to say something will happen in a certain amount of time (e.g. Im coming in three minutes), you add the word  after the time -      . Note: even though  means "around", this does **not** mean "I am coming in around three minutes".

Even though in English you say in three minute*s*, in Yiddish you just use the singular for minute, *  *. Another example is with hours - in seven hours is in the singular,   ** .

 has two meanings: to walk and to go.

skills.name: Trip
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Going Somewhere?**

If youre talking about going to a certain place, the word you use for to depends on where youre going. If youre going to a named geographic location, such as a country, city, continent, etc, you would say . For example,    , I am traveling to Lithuania. However, if youre going somewhere else, such as a park, you use , as in,    , Im going to the park.

****

 can mean to travel in a vehicle, whether it's a train, car, or bus, or whether youre driving or just a passenger. There is also a special verb  if you want to highlight that you're driving.

**Going home**

 means home, but  means "homewards/towards home". Im going home is " / "

**In a language**

When saying something is in a certain language (e.g. the book is in English), you use  instead of .
Im speaking in Polish -    .
This book is in Yiddish -     .

**The Dative Case**

Until now, we've only learned about two cases: the nominative (for the subject of a sentence) and the accusative (for the object of a sentence). The third case in Yiddish is called the dative. In Yiddish, it can be used in several different context, including the indirect object and following a preposition. In the dative case, the feminine  becomes , and the masculine  and neuter  both become . For example,   is feminine. When adding the preposition , it becomes     .

****

|Type of adverb| Where| There | Here |
| -------- | --------- | --------- | --------- |
|Adverb of location (no motion)|  where| / there |  here |
|Preposition (to/from) + place|  prep. + where (whence) | / prep. + there (thence) |  prep. + here (hence) |
|Adverb of motion (place to which)|  to where (whither) |  to there (thither) |  to here (hither) |

** **

  is a set phrase, meaning "by foot".

skills.name: Siblings
skills.tipsAndNotes:
When using a direct object in a sentence (e.g. I see the *computer*), we use what is called the accusative case. The accusative case is another example of when the definite article changes, but only for masculine nouns. Even though computer () is masculine, the proper way to say I see the computer is    . This change only occurs for masculine nouns (with the definite article ). So in the sentence    , the definite article doesnt change, because it is feminine.

When the possessive pronoun is on its own, the ending can be affected:
*   ,   *
*   ,   * 
In these examples, the independent possessive pronoun changes its ending to match the object of the sentence. So with a masculine object, the possessive pronoun will end in .

The same is true with direct objects (accusative case), but as explained above, the masculine ending will change to , while the feminine and neuter remain the same.
   ,     ** - Masculine changes
    ,     ** - Neuter remains the same

Accusative endings: https://prnt.sc/tz6dn9

 means to be familiar with/to know something, such as a person, place, or thing.    , I know this person.   , I know her.

Just like in English you would say "I see *him* and not I see *he*, in Yiddish you would say    and not   . 
(Put a small chart showing the changes). 

 means "here" direction-wise, so "Come here" would be  , and "there" would be 
, , go there.

is a verb with two parts. You would conjugate the verb , and put  at the end, unchanged.
So,    , I like it. (Lit: I have it like). 
Another example would be    , I love you (lit: I have you like/love).

A select amount of nouns also end in - in the dative case (indirect object):

skills.tipsAndNotes:
**, , etc**

When you use a preposition with a neuter or masculine noun, for example "In + the house" then you would combine the preposition with the definite article to create the equivalent of "inthe". So    becomes  . This isn't a must, like de+el in Spanish-->del, but it is recommended to write like this.

 -->

 -->

 -->

 -->

 -->
 
For masculine nouns, you generally don't need to add a definite article after " and sometimes even for ".

    

   

     

   

    

   

These are all correct and mean the same thing; however, if you want to emphasize that you are going to *this* museum, then you should use .

skills.name: Suffix
skills.tipsAndNotes:
can mean two things:
1. Already,    , I am already here
2. Right now/This instant,   ! Come here right now/this instant!

skills.name: Complain
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Hot and cold**

In Yiddish, we don't say "I am cold" you would say "Me (dative) is cold" (  ), 
or
"It's cold for me" (  ). 
The same goes for several other senses, such as "hot", "nauseous", "uncomfortable".

**Adjective conjugations**

Adjectives are conjugated the same way definite articles are: for case and gender. The neuter case also has two special subcategories: when the noun is preceded by  (e.g.,  ) and when it is not (e.g.,  ,  ).

| Conjugation Table for | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter (with ) | Neuter (without ) | Plural
| -------- | --------- | -------- | -------- | -------- | -------- |
| **Nominative** |  |  |  |  | 
| **Accusative** |  |  |  |  | 
| **Dative** |  |  |  |  |

skills.name: Food 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
means to want to, not to be confused with the English "will". 
  , I want to eat.

  means *not yet*.

skills.name: How is it?
skills.tipsAndNotes:
** ? or  ?**

They both mean the exact same thing ("than"). The only difference is that after  you must use the nominative case and after  you must use the dative case.

 + dative

 + nominative

skills.name: Mealtime
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The plural and singular for male vegetarians are the same: .
 ,  .

In Jewish culture, /kosher means food that follows the strict dietary standards of traditional Jewish law, such as not mixing meat with dairy.  means anything that isn't .

 can mean "only/just", and also "but/rather" in the sense of "    ,   I am not eating treif, but kosher."

skills.name: Restaurant
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**There is no/There isn't any**

When saying "there isn't any" or "there is no" in Yiddish, you'd say   , or  . For example:

     = there is no pepper

****

 means "just" in the sense of "just like that", "just because" or "for no reason."

****

 is one of the most important days of the week for Jews. It is the day of rest, when one cannot work or many do not use any technology. There is a skill coming up teaching important vocabulary pertaining to Shabbos.

**Idiom**

     is an idiom meaning literally "I do not make any calculations". Figuratively, it means I don't poke into someone else's business. A good example of this can be when donating money, your friend might say "Don't donate to him/her, he/she uses the money to buy bad things!" then you might answer "    ; I just give him/her money, and let God figure out the rest. I am not here to judge/calculate their life.

** vs   **

 is a noun, meaning 'a morning'

   is an adverb, meaning in the morning.

skills.name: Classroom
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Grades**

In many Yiddish communities, grades don't go by number, but rather by alphabet. 

  = First grade.     = Second grade, etc.

** vs ?**

 is the noun; e.g., when counting, , , , or when saying "I want one" with no noun following it.

 is the adjective, i.e., when it's followed by a noun.

For comparison:

    (I want one apple)

vs.

   (I want one)

skills.name: Breakfast
skills.tipsAndNotes:
** vs **

 is hot cereal, such as oatmeal or farina.

 is cold cereal, such as Cheerios or Rice Krispies.

skills.name: Friends
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Suffixes in the Dative Case for Names**

Some names (usually, Jewish ones), when in the dative case (indirect object), get an )), so
    and not    .

**What to Call Your Parents**

/ vs /? They mean the same thing, but  and  are much more formal. Kind of like father/dad, but  is not necessarily as informal as "dad".

** vs ?**

 means because (not "while"!!), while  means "about" or "because of".

      . = I am happy because he is helping me.

     . = I am happy because *of* his help.

****

 can be used to mean at (someone)'s house. 

    (  ) I am by Mendl('s house). 

Some of you may be familiar with this due to Jewish American English syntax (I ate by her house yesterday).

****

 has 2 meanings, with 2 pronunciations.

, with the vowel "oo" (as in book), means "after", as in:

    = We are swimming *after* them.

, with the vowel sound "o" (as in enough), means "more", as in:

   , I want one *more*.

skills.name: Shop
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Good news! There is only one past tense. The same way English uses the verb "to have", Yiddish uses , so "I have eaten" =   
This means both, I have eaten, and I ate.

  means business as well as shop.

skills.name: Vacation
skills.tipsAndNotes:
When using cardinal directions (e.g. North, West) in a sentence, you usually say the word   before. Here are some cases and examples:
1. Traveling in a direction. For example, I am traveling westward/to the west is    
2. Comparing one area to another. For example, Is France to the west of Spain? is      ?

skills.name: Languages
skills.tipsAndNotes:
means anyway, and it's also often shortened to just  .

You may notice that some verbs have prefixes. In Yiddish grammar, this is called a converb.  (to introduce) is an example of this. When conjugating these types of words, the parts separate. Heres an example in the present tense:
She introduces me -    
The main (second) part of the verb is conjugated on its own and comes right after the subject, while the prefix gets pushed to the end.
In the past tense:
She introduced me -    
Because its past tense, the verb  is conjugated first as usual. The whole verb  is pushed to the end, and the  comes right before the main part of the verb, while the prefix stays at the beginning.

skills.name: Leisure
skills.tipsAndNotes:
We saw the first example of a separable verb in the previous module. There are a few more examples in this one: , . Remember, you conjugate the second part of the verb, and in some case the prefix appears separate from the main part of the verb.

 means the actual tangible TV, while  is the content you watch. This difference exists in English too, but more subtly: "I'm watching TV" versus "I'm looking at the TV".

skills.name: Caring
skills.tipsAndNotes:
vs  - Both mean bother, but in different contexts.
 is used in the context of bothering someone/something, such as when I hug my cat, it bothers her, or when I bother my brother and don't let him do his homework. 
 is more like to care about something, such as It doesn't bother me that my cat sleeps all day, or It doesn't bother my mother when I call her 500 times a day.
 is similar to , except it's a separable verb. 

There are several ways to say you like something/someone: ,  , 
 is used in the context of food.
     - I do not like this food. (literally, the food doesnt smell to me)

 means it pleases me or its attractive to me. It introduces the dative case. Its similar to relevant words in other languages, like the Spanish 'me gusta.'
    - This chair pleases me, or I like this chair.

  can mean to love or to like and can be used in most cases, about people or things.
    - I love him. 

Similar to  , the verb for hate is  , and it works the same as  .
    I hate him.

skills.name: School
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Numbers in the 20-90s are said "backwards".
23 would be verbalized as "three-and-twenty" instead of the standard "twenty-three" in English.
Here are some examples:
 twenty-one (Lit: one and twenty)
 twenty-two (lit: two and twenty)
 thirty-nine (lit: nine and thirty)

skills.name: Furniture
skills.tipsAndNotes:
has three meanings: before, for, and in front of.
      - I eat an apple *before* lunch.
      - I have an apple *for* you.
     - I am *in front of* an apple.

=behind (Some Yiddish speakers don't pronounce the ) 
=under(neath)
=over
= between/among

skills.name: Shabbos
skills.tipsAndNotes:
is a feast - typically used to refer to a Shabbos or holiday meal.

Many people try to make the day special, either by preparing lavish meals or wearing nice clothes to honor the day. A common saying is   , meaning in honor of the holy Shabbos.

skills.name: Party
skills.tipsAndNotes:
A  is a celebration or a party, such as a birthday, Bar/Bat Mitzvah, a wedding, and so on.

Most verb in Yiddish use  in the past tense form (i.e. as an auxiliary verb). However, a few verbs use  instead. These verbs tend to have to do with motion or lack thereof. Some examples:
I went -   
They slept -   
We sat -

skills.name: Requests
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The imperative (commands) case in Yiddish is very simple. To command a single person, you conjugate the verb the same as the standard first person singular.
  , I go home ->  ! Go home! 
  . I eat babka ->  ! Eat babka!

To command multiple people, it's even simpler. All you have to do is remove the pronoun, so for example 
   You (all) eat bread
 ! Eat bread! (all of you/formal)!
   You run here
 ! Run here!

   is a set phrase which means again (literally, once more).

 vs .
 is used for asking questions, while  is used for asking for something (i.e. request). Just like you dont request for things in English, you also wouldnt say that in Yiddish.
For example,
   - I request money.

Use of /:
In Yiddish, like Spanish, French, and German, there are reflexive verbs. These verbs often refer to actions performed on oneself, but this is not always the case. In this course,  is used for the first person singular while  is used everywhere else*. Some verbs exist as both standard verbs and reflexive verbs, and in these situations its extra important to know which youre using.
For example:
   - can you take a seat?
  - can you punch/strike?
Alone,  means to hit, but as a reflexive verb, it means to sit.

*Note that in the YIVO standard, the reflexive is always .

skills.name: Numbers
skills.tipsAndNotes:
When using ordinal numbers, the endings must match the related noun. For example: 
   - I am the first one (masculine)
versus
     (feminine)

In the above example, the noun is the speaker. However, this is not always the case. For example:
     - I am the first captain
Note that  will always appear masculine in this sentence even if used by a female speaker, because the related noun (captain) is masculine. This can get even trickier when the noun is implied but not verbalized (e.g. in a discussion about captains, someone can just say    ).

Ordinal numbers (usually used with the proper endings):
 - first
 - second
 - third
 - fourth
/ - fifth
 - sixth
 - seventh
 - eighth
 - ninth
 - tenth

The format for dates in Yiddish is adding  after the cardinal number. For example:
    
An exception is when the cardinal number ends in a , then  is added:

skills.name: Clothes
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###Vocab
*  means to carry but it also means to wear.

* The plural of  is  (dresses). Note though, that  also just means clothing! Another synonym for clothing to avoid confusion is , although it is less widely used.

*  (pants) doesnt have a singular form. You might think its , but that actually means house!

###Grammar
* In Yiddish, you don't use the possessive as much as in English when talking about body parts; meaning, you wouldn't say "I put on *my* jacket" but rather "I put on the jacket." unless you want to specify that it is *your* jacket that you're putting on, and not someone else's.

*  , to get dressed, is a separable verb. You conjugate the  part, but not .
Example:
>I am getting dressed -    

* If you're putting on an article of clothing then you use the accusative (direct object) for the article of clothing along with the reflexive pronoun. As a reminder, with the accusative case, the definite article often changes.
Example:
>   **  **  - I am putting on the coat

Note: The  in this sentence is indicating the reflexive nature of the verb. In this usage,  is the first-person form of . For all other pronouns, you would just use .
Example:
>     . You put on the/your shoes. 

*   works in the same way that   does.

Examples:
>     - He is getting undressed
>       - He takes off the coat

skills.name: University
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###Vocab
** vs ?**

* Both words are used to compare and have the same meaning. Example:
>    * * =    * * = I am older than you (plural)

The only difference, as you can see, is that the word  is a preposition in Yiddish, so it introduces the dative case, and thus it's  and not . However,  on the other hand, is an adverb in this case, thus after it comes the nominative case and NOT the dative case.

###Grammar
* Like the word  , there are hundreds of Yiddish verbs that are compound verbs (not the same as separable verbs). Many of these compoud verbs consist of one word or Hebrew origin and one Yiddish word (usually , , , or ). 

An example of this is  . On its own,  does not mean anything in Yiddish, but combined with the verb ", it means "to explain." When using this compound verb, the  is the part thats conjugated. Example:
>  : I explain

>  : you explain

>...    : he explains ... to her.

skills.name: Hanukkah
skills.tipsAndNotes:
####Hanukkah
The Jewish festival of Hanukkah () is a celebration of a miracle that took place during the second century B.C.E. The miracle was *two-fold*: The Jews were successful in their revolt of their Greek-Syrian oppressors (led by King Antiochus IV) and after their Second Temple was looted, the only oil that was left burned for eight days (though it was only enough for one), allowing them time to prepare more oil. Hanukkah is celebrated in many ways: lighting the menorah, eating fried foods (e.g. latkes and doughnuts), and playing dreydl (a four-sided spinning top) are a few examples.

skills.name: Pets
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###Vocab
** vs **

Both mean animal. A  is any animal, while a  usually refers to bigger animals or cattle that are found on farms, such as cows, sheep, goats, and even camels.  does not include animals such as snakes.

* In some dialects,  is another term for "cow."

** vs **

Both mean to eat.  is the general term.  is used specifically to indicate *gorging* on food. Humans and animals alike can  or  their food, depending on how quickly/in what manner they are eating.

****

 can mean without, but it can also mean "onward" in the sense of "From now on..." or "Starting from now" or from here and onward. Example:
>    - From now on

>     - From this house and on(ward)

>    - Starting from today/from today on

Examples:

> * *    - A different kid says this

The only exception is when the noun is implied. Examples:

>       * * - Take this orange because its a different one.

****

 can also mean other people. Example:

skills.name: Whose
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Grammar**

*Possessive*

In Yiddish, just like in English, the genitive (possessive) case is simply done by adding  to the end of the word. Note that unlike in English, there is no apostrophe before the . Examples:

>    - Your mothers house

>    ? - Whose house is this?


When using the possessive for nouns, such as "The dog's bed", you would introduce the dative case, so it would be   . Examples:

>    - The sisters cat ( is feminine)

**

 is the possessive third person plural. Example:

>     - That is their house.

skills.name: Does!
skills.tipsAndNotes:
** Emphasis **

In order to enforce positive emphasis that you *do* do something, you would say . Example:
>     - You cant cook. ---->
   **  - Yes, I *can* cook

The opposite would be . Example:
>     - I can dance well ---->
 ,   **  - No, you *do not* dance well

skills.name: Learning
skills.tipsAndNotes:
** vs **

*  is to let go. It is a separable verb. Example:
>     - Let go of my hand

*  is to let/allow. Example:
>    - Let me go

** vs **

*  means to tell, usually a story. Example:
>     - Tell us a story

*  means to study/review material, such as for an exam. Example:
>       - I need to study/review for my exam

**  = **

 is a contraction of  . It functions just like let's in English.

skills.name: Purim
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**The Jewish Calendar and Purim**

Unlike the solar Gregorian calendar, the Jewish calendar, known in Yiddish as the , is lunisolar (months are dependent on the moon, years are based on the sun). The  also has twelve months, but with distinct names. For example, the month during which we celebrate the festival of Purim, is called  (usually around February/March). A unique feature of the  is that a leap month is added every few years.

Purim is a celebration of when the Jewish people were saved from Haman, an official in the Persian Empire, who was planning on killing them. Two important individuals who led to the positive outcome are Queen Esther and her uncle Mordechai. The story and events are recounted in the Book of Esther. Purim is a one-day celebration, during which children dress up in costume, the Book of Esther is read, gifts of food are exchanged, and charity is given.

*Laundry*

Instead of *doing* laundry, in Yiddish we *wash* laundry. Example:

*     ?       - When will you do (wash) the laundry? I have too much dirty laundry

Although  has " in it, you still use the accusative for the direct object.

skills.name: Passover
skills.tipsAndNotes:
****

*The Story*

Passover is an eight-day (seven-day, in Israel) holiday celebrated in the Jewish month of  (usually April/May) that commemorates the miracle of God bringing the Jewish people out of slavery from Egypt. In commemoration of the story that their dough didnt have time to rise as they rushed to leave Egypt, we eat  (unleavened bread) but dont eat   (leaven) during the entire holiday. In preparation of the holiday, we clean our houses to ensure no  is found.

* *

The iconic part of the Passover celebration is the , a multi-part ritual feast that includes the retelling of the story of the Exodus from Egypt, guided by the text of the .

Two highlights from the  :

* Throughout the , we drink four cups of wine. We also leave a cup for   in the hope that he will come to announce the arrival of  (Messiah).

* The leader of the  hides part of the main , called the . Traditionally, the children search for it, and once its found, its eaten as the dessert - the final food of the .

* *

The  happens on the first night of Passover (and on the second night, outside of Israel). The beginning and end of Passover are celebrated similar to Shabbos, in that no work is allowed. The middle days, called  , have looser restrictions - some people have traditions to do less work, but others treat it like a standard day (minus the eating of ).

skills.name: Future
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Grammar**

*Future*

In Yiddish, the future tense is formed with the verb  (not to be confused with the infinitive for the verb to want=).

![](https://imgur.com/XtQhHUR.png)

Examples:

*  **   - I will eat rice

*  **    - We will want to buy apples

*  **    - I will learn Italian

*  **   - What will he do?

*Everyone*

* in the nominative: /

Examples:

>     - Everyone is important

 and   are synonymous, and the same is true for  and  . Another way to say everyone is , all. Like in English, all words meaning everyone are considered third person singular, so it conjugates the same as "he/she".


* vs *

*  - Happening in the past tense

Examples:

skills.name: Diminutive
skills.tipsAndNotes:
and  are all used when talking to ones own parents, like mommy/mom/mama, daddy/dad/papa, grandpa/pawpaw, grandma/nana/mawmaw etc

Most diminutives are formed by adding  to the end of the word. There are some vowel changes when forming the diminutive case. This isn't always true though. https://prnt.sc/u17hpc
Essentially all words in the diminutive case are neuter, and the plural is usually -. example: 
( ,  ,  ,   ). 
When talking about children's body parts usually the diminutive case is used. It not only shows more affection but can also make the object sound smaller and daintier, like  sounds like booklet rather than a book, or  is like a boat rather than a ship, . 

*NOT ALL WORDS CAN BE MADE DIMINUTIVE*

Many names can also be made diminutive by adding . 
-->, David.

Some exceptions to this include , which is plural and can get the diminutive ending  meaning kids, but nobody would say  for a small child.  means a small child, it's an endearing term, kind of like saying "Squirt" in English.

the difference here is that when using  in this case, it gives it a 'human' sense, so, when saying    it means it gets changed, whether on its own, or through human help, but when saying     , it means that there is a person, or many people changing the thing every day.

Prepositions can sometimes be combined with the definite pronoun:

skills.name: Cute!
skills.tipsAndNotes:
You've learned the diminutive, now imagine a way to make words even smaller and possibly more affectionate sounding. Well, Yiddish has what is called a second-degree of diminutive, or the iminutive case. This case works very similarly to the diminutive case a few lessons back. In order to make something in the iminutive case, there usually is the same vowel changes as seen in the diminutive cases, such as 
 --> , or 
 --> 

In order to form the iminutive case, you must add an  before and after the . For example, 
 --> --> . 
 --> --> . 
This is usually used to describe things that belong to babies, whether it's their foot () or their shoes (). 

 and  are like ma and pa in English when referring to your parents. 
 and , although they sound like little tiny cute fathers and mothers, it really is not used in that context. When calling a little kid  or , depending on his or her gender, it's kind of like saying sweetie or darling.

 is one of the other really irregular (d)iminutives.

skills.name: Religion
skills.tipsAndNotes:
does not mean faith as in religion or belief. It just means faith in the context of having faith in someone or something.
 and  are basically very holy, spiritual people, like a Rabbi, but more righteous and holy. They are very important figures in Judaism. 
Not to be confused with  which just means charity. 
Where Jews live, it is common to find Jews knocking on people's door to collect money for charity for an organization, school, etc.

While  means modest in terms of clothing, it's mostly referring to the rules of dressing for females, such as wearing clothing that covers the collar bone, knees, and elbows. If something aligns by these rules, then the woman is .  The article of clothing is .

A  means a craze someone has or does, kind of like a weird quirk or weird shenanigan they like to do. For example, a  can be that when someone eats, they need to listen to music. Another  can be that when they sleep, they like sleeping with 2 blankets. Or when getting your nails painted, you ask the nail technician if they speak another language and if they don't you recommend duolingo to them. 

While  means to faint, it's kind of used in the same way "to die" in English is used. Like "I am dying to see him!"     !

, or "sit-meat" means your perseverance in staying still.  When you have ADHD you have no .

I am literally not going!    ! 
It also means "really" or "exactly/specifically".
    ! It was exactly/precisely this car!
 if something is supposed to happen it will happen because it is , it's meant to be/happen.       . It is meant to be that I did not see him.

skills.name: Abbreviation
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In Yiddish, abbreviations are usually done with an apostrophe or a double apostrophe, or gershayim (), depending on the word. Do not confuse the gershayim with a quotation mark ( vs ). 
In English, abbreviations can be done by just shortening the word and adding a period after the abbreviation, this does not always work in Yiddish. 

Miss Smith-->Ms. Smith
 --> .

Doctor Smith-->Dr. Smith
 --> .

Some abbreviations do have periods in Yiddish. 
-->.../..

skills.name: Forgive me!
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Yiddish has inherited many words from ancient Hebrew, these are collectively called "lushn-koydesh" or "loshn koydesh" words (lushn-koydesh meaning "the holy tongue").

#Spelling
These words are traditionally written the way they are in Hebrew, which doesn't follow Yiddish spelling rules.

1.  can also represent the sound _V_;

2. vowels are rarely spelled out;

3. the vowel  can represent either an _U_, or an _OY_ (_OY_ in closed lushn-koydesh syllables usually becomes _O_, so while a merchant is a *soykher*, the plural form is *sokhrim*).

#Verb conjugation 
The way verbs of lushn-koydesh-origin are formed can be a bit confusing at first, but once you get the hang of it it's really very simple.

Very few verbs blended completely into Yiddish and conjugate the way Yiddish verbs do. Examples are , .

Most verbs however, are just said in their infinitive form along with an auxiliary verb which conjugates for past present future, first second or third person. This auxiliary is in addition to the auxiliary used to form the past tense.

So as an example we have the verb "to succeed". The infinitive  (*matzliyekh*) is used along with the auxiliary . So "I succeeded" - "   ",
 "I will succeed" - "   ".

The marriage contract is called a .

In Yiddish, to say "Once upon a time" we say "  ... so "Once upon a time, there was a princess who...

Verbs like   , ,  ,   are called periphrastic verbs in Yiddish. The auxiliary verbs  and  are conjugated just as they would be with regular verbs; however, whether they take  or  in the present/future, they all take  in the past tense. For example:
   .
  .
   .

   .
  .
   .

skills.name: Chassidish
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The dialect spoken by Chassidim is the most spoken dialect in today's day. The dialect is heavily based on that of Central Yiddish (or Polish-Hungarian Yiddish). 

#Spelling
Although not taught in the course, Chassidish spelling is varied. Since Chassidim tend to be unaware of the standardization of Yiddish spelling, they spell words however they sound to them; this means you might see **** spelled as ****, or **** as ****. 

As seen in the Litvish skill, the **silent alef** in the middle of the word is usually used to avoid confusion. "Thus  will be spelled , and  will be spelled , etc".

#Vocabulary
Many Chassidim use English words for technical terms, such as medical terminology. In this course, however, we tried to remain true to the Yiddish language, so we did not teach any anglicized vocabulary. 
There are major differences between YIVO and Chassidish Yiddish. Here are some of them:

1. The use of an additional pronoun for the familiar second-person plural, or "you all/you guys" in English.

     **** (nominative) 

     **** (accusative/dative)

     **** (possessive)

2. The lack of genders. // formed into just ****. Some gender of words did, however, stay in set phrases, such as "   and " . 

3. Although all definite pronouns changed from // to just , two new definite pronouns appeared: , .

     **** meaning "this", and
      "" meaning "This (noun)" or "this one."

skills.name: Litvish
Synonyms
skills.tipsAndNotes: This skill is meant to teach you how to say the same word in more than one way. Some of them are used more in certain dialects vs other ones, and some might just be a big spelling change.
